fields.toaster_info_text:
Procedure:

- Manage according to the local protocol for rapid assessment and management

- Refer urgently to hospital!

Procedure:

- Refer urgently to hospital for further investigation and management!

fields.text: Hypertension and symptom of severe pre-eclampsia: {symp_sev_preeclampsia}
fields.toaster_info_text:
Procedure:

- Refer urgently to hospital for further investigation and management!

Procedure:

- Refer to hospital

- Revise the birth plan

Procedure:

- Give magnesium sulphate

- Give appropriate anti-hypertensives

- Revise the birth plan

- Refer urgently to hospital!

Procedure:

- Insert an IV line

- Give fluids slowly

- Refer urgently to hospital!

Procedure:

- Check for fever, infection, respiratory distress, and arrhythmia

- Refer for further investigation

Procedure:

- Give oxygen

- Refer urgently to hospital!

Procedure:

- Inform the woman that you cannot find the heartbeat and need to refer her to check if there's a problem.

- Refer to hospital.

v_required.err: Enter reason hospital referral was not done

fields.accordion_info_text:
Lowering daily caffeine intake during pregnancy is recommended to reduce the risk of pregnancy loss and low-birth-weight neonates.

This includes any product, beverage or food containing caffeine (e.g. brewed coffee, tea, cola-type soft drinks, caffeinated energy drinks, chocolate, caffeine tablets). Caffeine-containing teas (black tea and green tea) and soft drinks (colas and iced tea) usually contain less than 50 mg per 250 ml serving.

[Caffeine intake folder]
fields.accordion_info_title: Caffeine reduction counseling

fields.accordion_info_text: Healthcare providers should routinely offer advice and psycho-social interventions for tobacco cessation to all pregnant women who are either current tobacco users or recent tobacco quitters.
fields.accordion_info_title: Tobacco cessation counseling

fields.accordion_info_text: Provide pregnant women, their partners and other household members with advice and information about the risks of second-hand smoke (SHS) exposure from all forms of smoked tobacco, as well as strategies to reduce SHS in the home.
fields.accordion_info_title: Second-hand smoke counseling

fields.accordion_info_text: Advise to use condoms to prevent Zika, HIV and other STIs. If necessary, re-assure it is ok to continue to have sex during pregnancy.
fields.accordion_info_title: Condom counseling

fields.accordion_info_text: Healthcare providers should at the earliest opportunity advise pregnant women dependent on alcohol or drugs to cease their alcohol or drug use and offer, or refer them to, detoxification services under medical supervision, where necessary and applicable.
fields.accordion_info_title: Alcohol / substance use counseling

fields.text: Non-pharma measures to relieve nausea and vomiting counseling
fields.accordion_info_text: Ginger, chamomile, vitamin B6 and/or acupuncture are recommended for the relief of nausea in early pregnancy, based on a woman’s preferences and available options. Women should be informed that symptoms of nausea and vomiting usually resolve in the second half of pregnancy.
fields.accordion_info_title: Non-pharma measures to relieve nausea and vomiting counseling

fields.text: Pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting counseling
fields.accordion_info_text: Pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting, such as doxylamine and metoclopramide, should be reserved for those pregnant women experiencing distressing symptoms that are not relieved by non-pharmacological options, under the supervision of a medical doctor.
fields.accordion_info_title: Pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting counseling

fields.text: Diet and lifestyle changes to prevent and relieve heartburn counseling
fields.accordion_info_text: Advice on diet and lifestyle is recommended to prevent and relieve heartburn in pregnancy. Antacid preparations can be offered to women with troublesome symptoms that are not relieved by lifestyle modification.
fields.accordion_info_title: Diet and lifestyle changes to prevent and relieve heartburn counseling

fields.text: Antacid preparations to relieve heartburn counseling
fields.accordion_info_text: Antacid preparations can be offered to women with troublesome symptoms that are not relieved by lifestyle modification. Magnesium carbonate and aluminium hydroxide preparations are probably unlikely to cause harm in recommended dosages.
fields.accordion_info_title: Antacid preparations to relieve heartburn counseling

fields.text: Non-pharmacological treatment for the relief of leg cramps counseling
fields.accordion_info_text: Non-pharmacological therapies, including muscle stretching, relaxation, heat therapy, dorsiflexion of the foot, and massage can be used for the relief of leg cramps in pregnancy.
fields.accordion_info_title: Non-pharmacological treatment for the relief of leg cramps counseling

fields.text: Magnesium and calcium to relieve leg cramps counseling
fields.accordion_info_text: If leg cramps are not relieved with non-pharma measures, then give 300–360 mg magnesium per day in two or three divided doses; give calcium 1 g twice daily for two weeks.
fields.accordion_info_title: Magnesium and calcium to relieve leg cramps counseling

fields.text: Dietary modifications to relieve constipation counseling
fields.accordion_info_text: Dietary modifications to relieve constipation include promoting adequate intake of water and dietary fibre (found in vegetables, nuts, fruits and whole grains).
fields.accordion_info_title: Dietary modifications to relieve constipation counseling

fields.text: Wheat bran or other fiber supplements to relieve constipation counseling
fields.accordion_info_text: Wheat bran or other fiber supplements can be used to relieve constipation, if dietary modifications are not enough, and if they are available and appropriate.
fields.accordion_info_title: Wheat bran or other fiber supplements to relieve constipation counseling

fields.text: Regular exercise, physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture to relieve low back and pelvic pain counseling
fields.accordion_info_text: Regular exercise throughout pregnancy is recommended to prevent low back and pelvic pain. There are a number of different treatment options that can be used, such as physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture, based on a woman’s preferences and available options.
fields.accordion_info_title: Regular exercise, physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture to relieve low back and pelvic pain counseling

fields.text: Non-pharmacological options for varicose veins and oedema counseling
fields.accordion_info_text: Non-pharmacological options, such as compression stockings, leg elevation and water immersion, can be used for the management of varicose veins and oedema in pregnancy, based on a woman’s preferences and available options.
fields.accordion_info_title: Non-pharmacological options for varicose veins and oedema counseling

fields.text: Healthy eating and keeping physically active counseling
fields.accordion_info_text:
Healthy eating and keeping physically active during pregnancy is recommended for pregnant women to stay healthy and to prevent excessive weight gain during pregnancy.

[Nutritional and Exercise Folder]
fields.accordion_info_title: Healthy eating and keeping physically active counseling

fields.text: Increase daily energy and protein intake counseling
fields.accordion_info_text:
Increase daily energy and protein intake to reduce the risk of low-birth-weight neonates. 

[Protein and Energy Sources Folder]
fields.accordion_info_title: Increase daily energy and protein intake counseling

fields.text: Balanced energy and protein dietary supplementation counseling
fields.accordion_info_text: Balanced energy and protein dietary supplementation is recommended for pregnant women to reduce the risk of stillbirths and small-for-gestational-age neonates.
fields.accordion_info_title: Balanced energy and protein dietary supplementation counseling

fields.accordion_info_text:
Counseling:

- Advice to reduce workload and to rest- Advise on danger signs

- Reassess at the next contact or in 1 week if 8 months pregnant

- If hypertension persists after 1 week or at next contact, refer to hospital or discuss case with the doctor, if available
fields.accordion_info_title: Hypertension counseling

fields.accordion_info_text:
Counseling:

- Refer to HIV services

- Advise on opportunistic infections and need to seek medical help

- Proceed with systematic screening for active TB
fields.accordion_info_title: HIV positive counseling

fields.accordion_info_text:
Counseling:

- Provide post-testing counselling

- Request confirmatory Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT)

- Refer to hospital
fields.accordion_info_title: Hepatitis B positive counseling

fields.accordion_info_text:
Counseling:

- Provide post-testing counselling

- Request confirmatory Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT)

- Refer to hospital
fields.accordion_info_title: Hepatitis C positive counseling

fields.accordion_info_text:
Procedure:

- If primary or secondary stage of syphilis, please give single dose of benzathine penicillin 2.400.000 IU

- If late or unknown stage of syphilis, please give one dose of benzathine penicillin 2.400.000 IU weekly for 3 consecutive weeks

- Advise on treating her partner

- Encourage HIV testing and counselling

- Reinforce use of condoms
fields.accordion_info_title: Syphilis counselling and treatment

fields.accordion_info_text: A seven-day antibiotic regimen is recommended for all pregnant women with asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) to prevent persistent bacteriuria, preterm birth and low birth weight neonates.
fields.accordion_info_title: Seven-day antibiotic regimen for asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB)

fields.accordion_info_text:
Reassert dietary intervention and refer to high level care.

[Nutritional and Exercise Folder]
fields.accordion_info_title: Diabetes counseling

fields.accordion_info_text:
If a woman is diagnosed with anaemia during pregnancy, her daily elemental iron should be increased to 120 mg until her haemoglobin (Hb) concentration rises to normal (Hb 110 g/L or higher). Thereafter, she can resume the standard daily antenatal iron dose to prevent re-occurrence of anaemia.

The equivalent of 120 mg of elemental iron equals 600 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 360 mg of ferrous fumarate, or 1000 mg of ferrous gluconate.

[Iron sources folder]
fields.accordion_info_title: Prescribe daily dose of 120 mg iron and 2.8 mg folic acid

fields.accordion_info_text: Treat according to local protocol and/or refer for treatment.
fields.accordion_info_title: TB screening positive counseling

fields.accordion_info_text:
Provide comprehensive HIV prevention options:

- STI screening and treatment (syndromic and syphilis)

- Condom promotion

- Risk reduction counselling

- PrEP with emphasis on adherence

- Emphasize importance of follow-up ANC contact visits
fields.accordion_info_title: HIV risk counseling

fields.accordion_info_text: Oral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) containing tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) should be offered as an additional prevention choice for pregnant women at substantial risk of HIV infection as part of combination prevention approaches.
fields.accordion_info_title: PrEP offering framework

fields.accordion_info_text:
Please provide appropriate counseling for GDM risk mitigation, including:

- Reasserting dietary interventions

- Reasserting physical activity during pregnancy
fields.accordion_info_title: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) risk counseling

fields.accordion_info_text:
Danger signs include:

- Headache

- No fetal movement

- Contractions

- Abnormal vaginal discharge

- Fever

- Abdominal pain

- Feels ill

- Swollen fingers, face or legs
fields.accordion_info_title: Seeking care for danger signs counseling

fields.accordion_info_text: It is recommended that a woman sees a healthcare provider 8 times during pregnancy (this can change if the woman has any complications). This schedule shows when the woman should come in to be able to access all the important care and information.
fields.accordion_info_title: ANC contact schedule counseling

fields.text: Birth preparedness and complications readiness counseling

fields.accordion_info_text:
To enable mothers to establish and sustain exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months, WHO and UNICEF recommend:

- Initiation of breastfeeding within the first hour of life

- Exclusive breastfeeding – that is the infant only receives breast milk without any additional food or drink, not even water

- Breastfeeding on demand – that is as often as the child wants, day and night

- No use of bottles, teats or pacifiers
fields.accordion_info_title: Breastfeeding counseling

fields.accordion_info_text:
Due to the population's high anaemia prevalence, a daily dose of 60 mg of elemental iron is preferred over a lower dose. A daily dose of 400 mcg (0.4 mg) folic acid is also recommended.

The equivalent of 60 mg of elemental iron is 300 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 180 mg of ferrous fumarate, or 500 mg of ferrous gluconate.

[Iron sources folder]
fields.accordion_info_title: Prescribe daily dose of 60 mg iron and 0.4 mg folic acid

fields.accordion_info_text: In areas with a population prevalence of infection with any soil-transmitted helminths 20% or higher OR a population anaemia prevalence 40% or higher, preventive antihelminthic treatment is recommended for pregnant women after the first trimester as part of worm infection reduction programmes.

Intermittent preventive treatment in pregnancy of malaria with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (IPTp-SP) is recommended in malaria endemic areas. Doses should be given at least one month apart, starting in the 2nd trimester, with the objective of ensuring that at least three doses are received.
Sleeping under an insecticide-treated bednet and the importance of seeking care and getting treatment as soon as she has any symptoms.

Tetanus toxoid vaccination is recommended for all pregnant women who are not fully immunised against TT to prevent neonatal mortality from tetanus.

1-4 doses of TTCV in the past:

- 1 dose scheme: Woman should receive one dose of TTCV during each subsequent pregnancy to a total of five doses (five doses protects throughout the childbearing years).

TTCV not received or unknown:

- 3 doses scheme:

- 2 doses, 1 month apart

- 2nd dose at least 2 weeks before delivery

- 3rd dose 5 months after 2nd dose

Counseling:
- Provide post-testing counselling
- Advise retesting and immunisation if ongoing risk or known exposure
Pregnant women should be vaccinated with trivalent inactivated influenza vaccine at any stage of pregnancy.

Advice:

- Divide the total dose into three doses, preferably taken at meal-time

- Iron and calcium should preferably be administered several hours apart rather than concomitantly

[Calcium sources folder]
fields.accordion_info_title: Prescribe daily calcium supplementation (1.5–2.0 g oral elemental calcium)

fields.accordion_info_text:
Give a dose of up to 10,000 IU vitamin A per day, or a weekly dose of up to 25,000 IU.

A single dose of a vitamin A supplement greater than 25,000 IU is not recommended as its safety is uncertain. Furthermore, a single dose of a vitamin A supplement greater than 25,000 IU might be teratogenic if consumed between day 15 and day 60 from conception.

[Vitamin A sources folder]
fields.accordion_info_title: Prescribe a daily dose of up to 10,000 IU vitamin A, or a weekly dose of up to 25,000 IU

fields.text:
Dietary supplements NOT recommended:

- High protein supplement

- Zinc supplement

- Multiple micronutrient supplement

- Vitamin B6 supplement

- Vitamin C and E supplement

- Vitamin D supplement
fields.toaster_info_text:
Vitamin B6: Moderate certainty evidence shows that vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) probably provides some relief for nausea during pregnancy.

Vitamin C: Vitamin C is important for improving the bioavailability of oral iron. Low-certainty evidence on vitamin C alone suggests that it may prevent pre-labour rupture of membranes (PROM). However, it is relatively easy to consume sufficient quantities of vitamin C from food sources.

[Vitamin C folder]

Vitamin D: Pregnant women should be advised that sunlight is the most important source of vitamin D. For pregnant women with documented vitamin D deficiency, vitamin D supplements may be given at the current recommended nutrient intake (RNI) of 200 IU (5 μg) per day.
